title-group.article-title: Variability of BTEX in Residential Indoor Air of Kolkata Metropolitan City

abstract.p: Mono-aromatic hydrocarbons, namely benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene and isomers of xylene (BTEX) were studied within a group of typical urban residences. The average residential indoor levels of BTEX were 42.0, 69.3, 22.8, 52.1 and 21.6 µg·m−3, respectively. The indoor level was found to be significantly dependent on the type of fuel used and extent of ventilation but not on location of the residence or kitchen placement inside the residence. The average indoor/outdoor concentration ratio observed for BTEX > 1; and this indicates the presence of indoor sources for these compounds along with infiltration of outdoor air. The relative variability of the target compounds reveals that indoor sources, other than domestic fuel, like consumer products, cooking, etc., contribute significantly for xylenes and least for benzene. Also with increasing ventilation, the intrusion of outdoor air has definite contribution in increasing the indoor level in descending order for benzene, toluene, m-, p-xylene and ethylbenzene. For o-xylene, a removal effect was observed with increasing rate of ventilation.

The human health risk estimation reveals that the average integrated lifetime cancer risk considering the exposure to benzene and ethylbenzene due to residing for only 15 years in such indoor conditions is 2.9 E−05, which is sufficiently higher than the acceptable risk of 1.0 E−06.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Due to advent of industrialisation all over the world, more and more people are switching to modern cleaner fuels like electricity, Liquefied Petroleum Gas/Compressed Natural Gas (LPG/CNG) at home rather than traditional fuels like biomass (e.g. wood, dung, crop residues) and coal. Three billion people worldwide, especially in developing countries, still use latter types of fuels indoors for home cooking and heating. This could affect the indoor air quality (IAQ), which has now become a significant environmental issue. The residents could be exposed to elevated levels of indoor smoke which could result in the premature deaths of an estimated 1.6 million people each year with women and children being most significantly affected [1–3]. In India, environmentalists have been successful to some extent in generating awareness among the mass and the country became one of the partners in “Partnership for Clean Indoor Air” launched at the World Summit for Sustainable Development in Johannesburg in September 2002. Many studies have been done in India on indoor radon level [4–8] and fungal/microbial profile of indoors in Indian condition. Lawrence and Taneja [9] has reported an IAQ survey of a few parameters such as CO, NO, NO2, SO2 and PM10 in the households of rural India. Also, fungal/microbial profile in indoors Indian condition has been reported [10,11] but a very few study has reported the status and variability of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in Indian residential indoors.

Combustion sources are mainly responsible for generation of about 4000 different types of VOCs. Due to their high volatility, mobility in vapour phase and ability to penetrate structure, these are the most likely pollutants in indoor environment. Indoor levels of VOCs are largely dependent upon the use of domestic fuel, style of cooking, smoking, etc. In addition to combustion, different types of construction materials, furnishings, paints, varnishes and solvents, adhesives, office equipment and consumer products also emit VOCs at relatively high concentrations to the indoor environments [12–19]. Among the volatile indoor air pollutants, mono-aromatic hydrocarbons, such as benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene and the isomeric xylenes (BTEX), are particularly abundant in the indoor environment [20–23]. Moreover, outdoor concentrations, meteorology, type of rooms, ventilation, presence of integral garages and the storage of hobby materials also can have an influence on the BTEX level [21,24].

Exposure to indoor air pollutants can produce a variety of health effects including effects on vision, hearing, growth and intelligence and learning; effects on the cardiovascular system and asthma. Key signs or symptoms associated with exposure to VOCs include conjunctival irritation, nose and throat discomfort, headache, allergic skin reaction, dyspnea, nausea, fatigue, dizziness, etc., [19,25–28].

Indoor levels of VOCs often exceed outdoor levels as much as up to tenfold [20,29,30]. Human exposure to VOCs varies substantially depending upon their indoor levels rather than outdoor or ambient level [31]. Time-based activity pattern for human shows that, most individuals especially in urban environment could spend most of their time in various indoor microenvironments; most important of them being the residential indoors [32]. In developed countries, indoor levels of VOCs have been widely studied and regulated [21,22,33–35]. Concerns over indoor environments are also increasing in developing countries. This study provides a survey of the level of mono-aromatic hydrocarbons in some residential indoors in an urban environment in India; their dependence upon various factors and probable health risks to the inhabitant there from.

sec.title: Sampling Sites
sec.p: The study was conducted on three communities distributed in the metropolitan city of Kolkata, India. The three communities clustered in the surrounding area with 2 km radius from each of the three ambient air monitoring stations in the north, central and south Kolkata. The communities represent the middle and lower middle income group, within a typical urban agglomeration. Details regarding the type of residences, family characteristics and socio-economic and dwelling conditions, fuel used, kitchen location and other factors potentially related to VOC exposure were investigated using a pre-designed questionnaire survey. All together, 45 residences were studied between March 2005 and June 2005 with informed consent.

sec.title: Air Sampling
sec.p: The selected residences were one- to three-room apartments and the air sampler was placed preferably in the living room or at the middle of the apartment depending upon the practical feasibility. Each event of air sampling was done during the active household hours (8 am to 1 pm) for 3–4 h. The residents were requested not to smoke inside the apartment during the sampling period to avoid biasness from smoking.

Indoor sampling was performed for mono-aromatic hydrocarbons at a height of about 1.0 m from floor level and 1–2 m away from any construction wall or other obstructions. The outdoor air sampling was carried out by sampling air in front of the window (or door where no proper window was available) of the apartment. The outdoor sampling units were guarded properly from precipitation and good air circulation around the sampler was ensured. Air was sampled by drawing air at the rate of 100 mL min−1 with a low-volume pump (SKC Inc, USA) fitted with a charcoal sorbent tube in a low flow holder. Sampling flow rates of all the pumps used were determined using Ultra-flo Calibrator (SKC Inc. USA) before and after sampling. Field blank and breakthrough tests were done to ensure quality control.

sec.title: Determination of Mono-aromatics
sec.p: After sampling, the charcoal was desorbed in 1 mL of carbon disulfide (CS2) for 1–1.5 h and analysed for benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene and three isomers of xylenes. Quantification was done using a Gas Chromatograph (Perkin Elmer, Auto System XL GC) equipped with a Flame Ionisation Detector (GC/FID). Separation of the analytes was achieved by PE 624 (Perkin Elmer) capillary column (length, 30 m; diameter, 0.32 mm; and film thickness, 1.80 µm), isothermally at 100°C. Detector and injector temperatures were maintained at 200°C and 180°C, respectively.

The samples were quantified against a five-point external calibration curve prepared from standard pure substances (Aldrich, USA) at different dilutions in CS2 containing each of the six analytes. Fluorobenzene was used as an internal standard to avoid injection error and error from trace benzene content in the solvent.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis of data was carried out using the MINITAB 13 software. Potential effects of various factors were analysed using one-way Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) test. Tukey's pair-wise test was carried out where ANOVA result showed significant difference [36].

sec.title: Description of the Household
sec.p: The nature of the fuel consumed, location and ventilation of the house and location of the kitchen were taken into consideration during collection of the samples. The populations studied were chosen from two socio-economic groups namely middle class (G1) and lower middle class (G2). It is observed that 49% of the studied households use LPG (f1) as domestic fuel, while 29% use kerosene (f2), and the rest 22% use a combination of kerosene and coal (f3); 9% of the selected residences has kitchen in an area just outside the apartment. The residential indoors were segregated according to the extent of ventilation. Residence without any proper window or window with obstruction was classified as “poor” (v1); residences having two or more windows per room with cross ventilation and/or with exhaust fan fitted in kitchen was classified as “good” (v3), the rest of the residences having ventilation in between were classified as “moderate” (v2).

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
The average residential indoor levels of benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, m-, p-xylene and o-xylene were: 42.0, 69.3, 22.8, 52.1 and 21.6 µg·m−3, respectively. The statistics of indoor and outdoor concentrations of BTEX are given in Table 1. Table 1.

A considerable variation in indoor concentrations was observed with large standard deviations across different residences studied. The ANOVA results show that the BTEX levels do not significantly vary with the locality (north, central or south Kolkata) or kitchen location (separate or integrated) inside the household, but are significantly dependent upon the type of domestic fuel used for cooking. BTEX levels were found to be highest in the residences using f3 followed by residences where only f2 was used and was least among the household using f1.

After performing Tukey's pair-wise comparison test, it was found that only for toluene, the three pairs were significantly different from each other (€p<0.01). For benzene and ethylbenzene, statistically significant divergence (€p<0.01) existed among f1–f3 and f2–f3; whereas for isomers of xylene, the difference was only among f1–f3 (€p<0.05). Indoor levels of benzene, toluene and ethylbenzene were significantly decreased with the extent of ventilation (€p<0.01), but the difference was not statistically significant for m-, p-xylene (€p = 0.15) and o-xylene (€p = 0.08). The indoor level was also extensively dependent on socio-economic condition as this was closely related to the practice of fuel usage and also the dwelling condition. This indicates that the use of coal particularly would elevate indoor BTEX level. Moreover, poor ventilation could constrain the effective dispersion of the gaseous pollutants resulting higher level of contamination.

sec.title: Indoor: Outdoor Ratio (I/O)
sec.p:
The I/O value, i.e. the ratio of the indoor (I) to the outdoor (O) air concentration of BTEX, could reveal the relationship between outdoor and indoor sources more effectively than the absolute concentrations. The indoor/outdoor ratios of BTEX monitored in all the households are shown in the Figure 1 (box-whisker plot). Fig. 1
Ratio of indoor and outdoor concentrations in all the residences. Note: The box for each component represents the middle 50% of the dataset. The upper edge of the box represents the 75th percentile of the data set, and the lower edge designates the 25th percentile. The line inside the box represents the median value of the dataset. The ends of the vertical lines or “whiskers” indicate the minimum and maximum data values. The points outside the ends of the whiskers are outliers.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The mean indoor versus immediate outdoor ratios were 1.3, 1.4, 1.3, 1.2 and 1.1 for BTEX, respectively. Highest I/O was found for toluene (5.8) and lowest for m-, p-xylene (0.1). The main source of mono-aromatic hydrocarbons in a typical urban area was attributed to be motor vehicle-related emissions [18,37], but here the I/O was greater than 1 indicated that apart from the intrusion of outdoor air, there could be presence of other indoor sources like emissions from domestic fuel used, cooking, consumer products, etc. which could have contributed some of these pollutants. Studies have shown that building materials and cleaning products are prominent sources of indoor VOCs [18,19,29,38]. The emission rates of gaseous pollutants in a residential indoor microenvironment may not be large, but the proximity of sources and impediment of dispersion would result in higher indoor level than immediate outdoors.

sec.title: Variability of BTEX with Fuel and Ventilation
sec.p: There could be multiple sources in a non-smoking indoor environment. In this study, the indoor BTEX concentrations were found to vary significantly with fuel used and extent of ventilation. It should be noted that rather than the absolute value of the coefficient of variability as well as the background value, the relative values are more significant here. The background levels of BTEX were found to be in the order: benzene<toluene ≈ ethylbenzene<o-xylene<m-, p-xylene. This implied that indoor sources, other than domestic fuel, like consumer products, cooking, etc., contributed significantly for xylenes and least for benzene concentrations. Coefficient of variability with respect to fuel shows a positive contribution for all the components, highest for toluene followed by isomers of xylenes, benzene and least for ethyl benzene. Coefficient of variability with respect to ventilation shows positive value for all the target components except o-xylene. This indicated that as the ventilation was increased, intrusion of outdoor air had a definite contribution in increasing the indoor levels, in the following descending order: benzene, toluene, m-, p-xylene and ethylbenzene. For o-xylene, the negative value of V would indicate a removal effect with the increasing rate of ventilation.

sec.title: Exposure Calculation
sec.p: Benzene is a known human carcinogen (classified as Group 1 carcinogen by International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) classification), and ethylbenzene is a possible human carcinogen (classified as Group 2B carcinogen by IARC classification) [39,40]. The average indoor level of benzene observed in this study (42.0 µg·m−3) is much higher than the WHO guideline for benzene of 5–20 µg·m−3 [25]. The level is also much higher than the annual Indian National ambient air quality standard for benzene (i.e. 5 µg·m−3). The lifetime cancer risk (ILCR) due to benzene and Ethylbenzene and also the non-cancer hazard due to exposure to BTEX at their prevailing level were estimated for a population living more than 15 years in such indoor conditions. Calculations of exposures to BTEX were based on indoor levels. Although time-based activity patterns, variation of intake fractions, mixture effects, and other factors affecting exposure and risk were not considered yet the cancer and non-cancer risk estimate will give an extent of probable health risk posed by these pollutants to the population under consideration.

sec.title: Calculation of Chronic Non-Cancer Hazard
sec.p: Non-cancer risks were expressed as hazard quotient (HQ), which is defined as the ratio of the yearly average daily doses received, EY and the reference dose, reference dose or RfD (a level below which adverse health effects are not likely to occur).
This algorithm was used to calculate chronic non-cancer risks based on chronic RfDs. The summation of HQs for individual contaminants would give Hazard Index (HI).

The mean HQs for the individual component or the HI values were less than 1 indicating no significant threat of non-cancer health effect. However, the HQ and HI values corresponding to benzene level exceeded the acceptable limit of 1 in 13% and 33% cases, respectively of the residences studied.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The prevailing level of BTEX in all the 45 urban residences studied in Kolkata was found to be quite high. The indoor level was significantly dependent on the type of fuel used and the extent of ventilation but not due to the location of the residence or kitchen placement inside the residences. The average indoor to outdoor concentration ratios for BTEX > 1 indicated the presence of indoor sources along with infiltration of outdoor air. The carcinogenic risk due to exposure of benzene and ethylbenzene was estimated to be 2.9 E−05, which is more than the acceptable risk of one in a million.
